body.value: James Wright introduces reading and poem by Ben Jonson “On My First Son”.
Reads poem by Ben Jonson, “On My First Son”.
Introuces poem translated by W.S. Merwin, by Frederico Garcia Lorca, “Garcela of Unforseen Love”.
Reads poem translated by W.S. Merwin, by Frederico Garcia Lorca “Garcela of        Unforseen Love”.
Introduces poem by Jonathan Swift, “On Burning a Dull Poem”.
Jonathan Swift published Gulliver’s Travels in 1725
expression of the Irish art of the curse
Reads poem by Jonathan Swift, “On Burning a Dull Poem”.
Introduces poem by John Millington Synge “Upon the Sister of the Critic who Attacked the Playboy”.
of the women on Erin Islands who cleaned his room
learnt from listening to rhythm of language
quote “What rare beauty is that now? What rare beauty at all”
play “The Playboy of the Western World” produced
Aristotle quote ‘poetry is a higher and more philosophical thing than history’

Introduces and reads poem by Rilke, first line “When the clocks nearby strike as if their own hearts were beating...”.
Reads in German poem by Rilke, first line “When the clocks nearby strike as if       their own hearts were beating...”.
Explains Rilke poem, introduces “A Note Left in Jimmy Leonard’s Shack”.

Reads “A Note Left in Jimmy Leonard’s Shack”.
Cut/edit in recording, sentence begins and then continues, repeated at lower quality sound, perhaps a tape change?
James Wright introduces “In Terror of Hospital Bills”.
from Shall We Gather at the River (Wesleyan University Press, 1968)

Introduces “A Poem Written Under an Archway in a Discontinued Railway Station, Fargo, North Dakota”.
Reads “A Poem Written Under an Archway in a Discontinued Railway Station,     Fargo, North Dakota”.
Unknown introducer thanks James Wright and introduces next reading, Mary-Lou Kaiser [?] on January 24th.
